That's up to you. It apparently wasn't up to you up until that point, according to the slogan order.
But now you have defined what the actual state depends on. Whether you can actually know it is a different question.
Right, not as words on a page, but I usually remember them as "a story", which is different from how I remember real events.

I first read it the way it was recommended on the prologue, but skipping some of the optional chapters and wandering around to read some random ones. When re-reading, I just read random chapters, one will remind me of another, and I go find that one. I still find connected chapters that I hadn't realized.

If the materials are worth more than the coin, what would prevent someone from getting a lot of those coins, melt them, and sell them for the material?
The cost of *making* it and the cost of the material are very different. You can offset the cost of making it because of the utility of using it multiple times. You can't prevent people from melting them if the metal is worth more.
It was also probably more expensive to make, in relative terms.

WRITING.TITLE: I love the way in which Hopscotch seems like a lived memory rather than a read one.
WRITING.TEXT: In the book, you can read the chapters in any order you like. I recently discussed this with a friend. Hopscotch (by Cortazar) is stored in my memory almost as a lived memory. I think it's because you have to read the story out of order and put together the chronology in your head. Similar to how in real life we remember things related to each other thematically, and then have to think harder to see what happened first.
I'll just sit here at the bottom with everyone else who is pointing out that it's really only 3D: two spacial dimensions, plus time.
Technically, all chess is 3D chess, since there are only two dimensions to move in, plus time.
I'm almost glad I never got to finishing the last one.
She says the dog survived.

Yes, it would basically be: is it accurate, and if not, is it in the spirit of the original?

WRITING.TITLE: What does it mean if you dream about doing mouth to mouth resuscitation to a dog?
WRITING.TEXT: My friend dreamt that she was doing mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to a black dog. The dog had choked on a snail, so she took the snail out with her finger first. She recently had a long-distance break-up. What does this mean?
It seems like a classic case of "project your biases here".
You could also do this with movie adaptations of books.
It would be great if you annotate it with specific scenes.
This is a shit-ton of work!
Also, music peaked in my teenager years, when I was most emotionally vulnerable.
Wood is probably a pretty good dielectric. And, at least in humans, lightning tends to travel on the surface.

WRITING.TITLE: This bird poop looks like a Jackson Pollock painting.

WRITING.TEXT: The damage looked recent.

Oh, I was supposed to post this in /r/askphysics first?
edit: why all the negatives? I'm just trying to figure this Reddit thing out.
The other side of the trunk had the same pattern, so I think it's unlikely that the pattern was due to branches resting against it.
I think so, too. Can't really think of any other sources of fire in the middle of the woods. But why would you expect a lightning to start burning near the base of the trunk?
It was definitely alive when it hit, and not hollow. I think it was still alive when I saw it. And it didn't seem to have been burning from the inside, it was from the surface in.

Hahaha. Yes, I've seen it happen on coals, but didn't know the word. And I guess I had never thought of wood as doing it. I still don't really know why combustion is sometimes with flame and sometimes smoldering, though.
I think that's the best way to approach the problem, as it implicitly accounts for the dynamics of human anatomy and physiology.
The comment died of success.
It looks like a massacre of Dr. Zoidberg's relatives.
Yes, I believe the key is the smoldering combustion. Like in the picture you shared.

Still unconvinced. Have you seen that weird shape in the middle? Why would the stream of water run down the tree like that?
I think it's more likely due to [smoldering](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smouldering) like a friend of mine suggested. That combustion is slower than flame combustion, and lower temperature. I guess it was smoldering without rain, and then rain started and stopped the whole process.
Another picture, closer up: https://imgur.com/gallery/4vzKV

Another picture: https://imgur.com/gallery/4vzKV
You can see that it's clearly burnt.
Unfortunately my phone battery died while taking those two and I couldn't take any more.

A friend suggested it may have started [smoldering](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smouldering) , which moves slower and at lower heat than flame combustion. Then, maybe the bark is less sensitive to smoldering so the burnt advances more in depth than in surface.

Lightning could explain how the fire started (although it would be weird that it would start so low, since lightning hits trees on the top and the top was healthy). But more importantly, lightning doesn't explain the weird shape of the burnt region or the precise boundary between burnt and unburnt regions.
But then, if it's raining, why would the bark-less trunk continue burning?

Above that, the tree was normal and healthy-looking.
Yes, it was definitely burnt.
It's obscure enough if you have to put a link to the wikipedia page when posting on r/phisicsjokes
That depends: will the male plant his seed between legs 1 and 2, or between legs 2 and 3?

WRITING.TITLE: How did this tree get burnt like that? Notice the weird shape of the burnt part, and that the unburnt part is completely untouched, even though the burnt part is burnt about an inch deep.
